messageBody:
@Colin,

It was a bit hard to read... but I understand your question to be... why bother to have an assertException() method:

74 /**
75 * This method asserts that a specified exception was thrown.
76 *
77 * @param expectedExceptionClass
78 * @param actualException
79 *
80 * @return boolean
81 */
82 public static boolean assertException(
83 final Class<? extends Throwable> expectedExceptionClass,
84 final Throwable actualException) {
85
86 if (expectedExceptionClass.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(
87 actualException.getClass().getName())) {
88 return true;
89 }
90
91 // Determine if a previous assertion failed error already occurred.
92 if (AssertionFailedError.class.isAssignableFrom(actualException.getClass())) {
93
94 // If so, re-throw the error.
95 throw (AssertionFailedError) actualException;
96
97 }
98
99 Assert.fail("The expected exception [" + expectedExceptionClass.getName()
100 + "] was not thrown.\n" + "However, an unexpected ["
101 + actualException.getClass().getName() + "] exception was thrown.");
102
103 return false;
104 }

There are a couple of primary points to be made:

1. The assert method ends 'cleanly' with an AssertionFailedError if the wrong exception was caught.

2. The assert method displays feedback listing the expected exception and the actual exception.

_Marvin
PatternEnabled.com
